snippet.title: Ask A Monk: Meditation and Mental Illness
snippet.description:
On whether meditation is suitable for people with mental illnesses.

Please submit questions to my YouTube Channel: http://www.youtube.com/yuttadhammo

and subscribe for updates here:

http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=yuttadhammo

http://www.google.com/moderator/#16/e=20ee8

and feel free to rate other people's questions so I know which are most important to answer.

snippet.title: Ask A Monk: Self-Consciousness and Courage
snippet.description: "Dear Brother Yuttadhammo, I am 17 years old and have been inspired by your methods of meditation. Can I use meditation to help deal with constant stress, anxiety, and self consciousness to be more courageous and more at peace with myself?"

snippet.title: Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: Ali Ashtari
snippet.description:
Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: Ali Ashtari

Premier of our new weekly guest series, talking to fellow Buddhist meditator and teacher, Ali Ashtari, about meditation, skepticism, atheists, and Iran.

snippet.title: Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: David Holmes
snippet.description:
Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: David Holmes

Sirimangalo Int'l Presents is our new weekly guest series where we talk to interesting people in the global Buddhist community.

In this episode we talk with David Holmes, a long-time Buddhist scholar and meditator in the Theravada tradition about his life and experience on the Buddhist path.

snippet.title: Buddhism 101: Generosity
snippet.description: Buddhism 101 is a series on basic Buddhist concepts, meant as a supplemental resource for Buddhist meditators.  This video is on the Buddhist concept of giving (daana).

snippet.title: Buddhism 101: Morality I
snippet.description: Buddhism 101 is a series on basic Buddhist concepts, meant as a supplemental resource for Buddhist meditators.  This video is first of four on the Buddhist concept of morality (siila).

snippet.title: Buddhism 101: Morality II
snippet.description: Buddhism 101 is a series on basic Buddhist concepts, meant as a supplemental resource for Buddhist meditators.  This video is second of four on the Buddhist concept of morality (siila).

snippet.title: Buddhism 101: Morality III
snippet.description: Buddhism 101 is a series on basic Buddhist concepts, meant as a supplemental resource for Buddhist meditators.  This video is third of four on the Buddhist concept of morality (siila).

snippet.title: Buddhism 101: Morality IV
snippet.description: Buddhism 101 is a series on basic Buddhist concepts, meant as a supplemental resource for Buddhist meditators.  This video is the last of four on the Buddhist concept of morality (siila).

snippet.title: Buddhism 101: Consequences
snippet.description: Buddhism 101 is a series on basic Buddhist concepts, meant as a supplemental resource for Buddhist meditators.  This video is on the consequences of wholesome and unwholesome deeds as a framework for reality.

snippet.description:
41. aciraṃ vatayaṃ kāyo, pathaviṃ adhisessati.
chuddho apetaviññāṇo, niratthaṃva kaliṅgaraṃ.

Video 29 in a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

For more information the dhammapada: http://www.buddhanet.net/e-learning/buddhism/dpreface.htm

snippet.title: Mahasi Sayadaw Biography 07 (rare footage) 馬哈希尊者傳
snippet.description:
Mahasi Sayadaw Biography 07, rare footage taken from the "Venerable Mahasi Sayadaw's Discourses and Treatises Buddhism MP3/DVD" issued by Mahasi Sasana Yeiktha in Yangon, Burma.

This particular video displays the late Sayadaw's dhamma preaching activities in Burma after he was wide known in the country after the 6th Buddhist Council in the 1950s.

snippet.title: Mahasi Sayadaw Biography 09 (rare footage) 馬哈希尊者傳
snippet.description:

This particular video displays the late Sayadaw's dhamma preaching activities in the United States upon the invitation of the Insight Meditation Society from Barre in US.

snippet.title: Swastika - Bringers of Well-being
snippet.description:
On the things that bring (ika) well-being (sva+asti = svasti) = swastika.

Swastika is a Sanskrit word that has nothing intrinsically to do with Nazi Germany.  The Pali equivalent is 'sovatthika' (su + atthi + ṇika) and is a name for certain qualities in the Buddha's teaching.

snippet.title: หลวงปู่ทอง:2JULY54อยู่เหนือมาร
snippet.description:
วีดีโอธรรมะบรรยาย ของพระธรรมมังคลาจารย์ สิริมงฺคโล(หลวงปู่ทอง)
 เรื่อง อยู่เหนือมาร (องค์บรรยายที่1)
ในงานธรรมะเปลี่ยนชีวิตครั้งที่4
มหาวิทยาลัยแม่โจ้ ร่วมกับ ชมรมสารธรรมล้านนา
ได้จัด การบรรยาย และปฏิบัติธรรม
วัน เสาร์ 2 กรกฎาคม 2554 ณ ศูนย์กีฬากาญจณาภิเษก รัชกาลที่ 9 ม.แม่โจ้
เวลา 7.00 น.-17.00น. ...ฟรี!..ทุกอย่างค่ะ
ในงานมีการแจกหนังสือธรรมะ-ซีดีธรรมะ
โรงทานเปิดตั้งแต่ 06.00น. "มีอาหารและเครื่องดื่มฟรีตลอดงาน"

snippet.title: 26.6.2010 สังฆทาน วัดพระธาตุศรีจอมทอง
snippet.description: ทําบุญ วัดที่ 4  ของ ทริปเชียงใหม่ ( 6 วัด ) พระเทพสิทธาจารย์ วิ. ( พระอาจารย์ทอง สิริมงฺคโล) ให้พร ชุดสังฆทานที่ถวายมี ซีดีmp3 หลวงพ่อพุธ ฐานิโย 10 แผ่น cdสมเด็จพระสังฆราชสอนกรรมฐาน หนังสือธรรมมะ เสียดายคนตายไม่ได้อ่าน กับ ณ มรณา มีดโกนขนนก 2 ด้าม และใบมีดรุ่นแพลททินัม 2 กล่อง กรรไกรตัดเล็บยี่ห้อ trim 2 อัน แหนบ ไม้แคะหู ยาต่างๆ ยาอมรสมะนาว 2 ชาร์โคลแคบซูล ฟ้าทะลายโจรแคปซูล 1 กระปุก ฯลฯ

snippet.title: How To Meditate For Children: A Kid's Guide to Peace
snippet.description:
A video on meditation for children.  It's a mixture of meditating on ideas (like cats, dogs, parents, etc.) and meditating on reality (sitting, breath, etc.).

For more information on how to meditate on reality, you can read my booklet that gives more specific instructions:

http://yuttadhammo.sirimangalo.org/articles/how-to-meditate/

NEW: Subtitle file available here:

http://static.sirimangalo.org/kids.sbv.zip

Download the subtitle file and translate it into your own language, then send me a message and I can upload it.

snippet.title: How To Meditate For Children #3: Love
snippet.description:
Third video in a series devoted to teaching children how to meditate.  This video focuses on a popular form of Buddhist meditation, that of loving-kindness or "metta" in Pali.

For more information on this type of meditation, please see:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mett%C4%81
http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/buddharakkhita/wheel365.html

snippet.title: How To Meditate For Children #4: Yourself
snippet.description:
Final video in a series devoted to teaching children how to meditate.  This video teaches insight meditation based on the four foundations of mindfulness (in this video, the fourth foundation is split into two parts).

For more information on this type of meditation, please read my booklet on how to meditate:

http://www.sirimangalo.org/teachings/how-to-meditate/

snippet.title: Dhammapada 1:  Suffering is Mind-made
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Verse 1 in Pāḷi: Yamaka

Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, 
manoseṭṭhā manomayā,
manasā ce paduṭṭhena 
bhāsati vā karoti vā,
tato naṁ dukkham anveti 
cakkaṁ va vahato padaṁ.

The background story can be found here:
https://what-buddha-said.net/Canon/Sutta/KN/Dhammapada.Verse_1.story.htm

.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse Two: Happiness Follows a Pure Mind
snippet.description:
manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, manoseṭṭhā manomayā.

manasā ce pasannena, bhāsati vā karoti vā.

tato naṃ sukhamanveti, chāyāva anapāyinī.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses Three and Four: Clinging to Perceived Wrongs Only Leads to More Wrong
snippet.description:
akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me.

ye ca taṃ upanayhanti, veraṃ tesaṃ na sammati.

akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me.

ye ca taṃ nupanayhanti, veraṃ tesūpasammati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses Seven & Eight: A Weak Tree and a Mountain of Solid Rock
snippet.description:
subhānupassiṃ viharantaṃ, indriyesu asaṃvutaṃ.

bhojanamhi cāmattaññuṃ, kusītaṃ hīnavīriyaṃ.

taṃ ve pasahati māro, vāto rukkhaṃva dubbalaṃ.


asubhānupassiṃ viharantaṃ, indriyesu susaṃvutaṃ.

bhojanamhi ca mattaññuṃ, saddhaṃ āraddhavīriyaṃ.

taṃ ve nappasahati māro, vāto selaṃva pabbataṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses Nine and Ten: Worthy of the Robe
snippet.description:
anikkasāvo kāsāvaṃ, yo vatthaṃ paridahissati.
apeto damasaccena, na so kāsāvamarahati.

yo ca vantakasāvassa, sīlesu susamāhito.
upeto damasaccena, sa ve kāsāvamarahati.

snippet.description:

te sāraṃ adhigacchanti, sammāsaṅkappagocarā.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 13 and 14: A Well-Thatched Roof
snippet.description:
yathā agāraṁ ducchannaṁ, vuṭṭhī samativijjhati.
evaṁ abhāvitaṁ cittaṁ, rāgo samativijjhati.

yathā agāraṁ suchannaṁ, vuṭṭhī na samativijjhati.
evaṁ subhāvitaṁ cittaṁ, rāgo na samativijjhati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 19 and 20: Who Partakes in the Fruit
snippet.description:
bahumpi ce saṁhita bhāsamāno, na takkaro hoti naro pamatto.
gopova gāvo gaṇayaṁ paresaṁ, na bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.

appampi ce saṁhita bhāsamāno, dhammassa hoti anudhammacārī.
rāgañca dosañca pahāya mohaṁ, sammappajāno suvimuttacitto.
anupādiyāno idha vā huraṁ vā, sa bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 21, 22, and 23: The Mindful Never Die
snippet.description:
21. appamādo amatapadaṁ, pamādo maccuno padaṁ.
appamattā na mīyanti, ye pamattā yathā matā.

22. evaṁ visesato ñatvā, appamādamhi paṇḍitā.
appamāde pamodanti, ariyānaṁ gocare ratā.

23. te jhāyino sātatikā, niccaṁ daḷhaparakkamā.
phusanti dhīrā nibbānaṁ, yogakkhemaṁ anuttaraṁ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 24: Glory to the Mindful
snippet.description:

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 26 and 27: Cherished Treasure
snippet.description:
pamādamanuyuñjanti, bālā dummedhino janā.
appamādañca medhāvī, dhanaṃ seṭṭhaṃva rakkhati.

mā pamādamanuyuñjetha, mā kāmaratisanthavaṃ .
appamatto hi jhāyanto, pappoti vipulaṃ sukhaṃ.

snippet.description:

saṃyojanaṃ aṇuṃ thūlaṃ, ḍahaṃ aggīva gacchati.

32. appamādarato bhikkhu, pamāde bhayadassi vā.
abhabbo parihānāya, nibbānasseva santike.

snippet.description:

phandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ, dūrakkhaṃ dunnivārayaṃ.
ujuṃ karoti medhāvī, usukārova tejanaṃ.

vārijova thale khitto, okamokataubbhato.
pariphandatidaṃ cittaṃ, māradheyyaṃ pahātave.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 42: Worse Than An Enemy
snippet.description:
42. diso disaṃ yaṃ taṃ kayirā, verī vā pana verinaṃ.
micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ, pāpiyo naṃ tato kare.

Whatever harm an enemy may do to an enemy, or a hater to a hater, an ill-directed mind inflicts on oneself a greater harm.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 43: Better Than A Blood-Relative
snippet.description:
43. na taṃ mātā pitā kayirā, aññe vāpi ca ñātakā.
sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ, seyyaso naṃ tato kare.

Neither mother, father, nor any other relative can do one 
greater good than one's own well-directed mind.

Video 31 in a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 44 & 45: Overcome the World
snippet.description:
44. ko imaṃ pathaviṃ vicessati, yamalokañca imaṃ sadevakaṃ.
ko dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ, kusalo pupphamiva pacessati .

45. sekho pathaviṃ vicessati, yamalokañca imaṃ sadevakaṃ.
sekho dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ, kusalo pupphamiva pacessati.

Video 32 in a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.description:
46. pheṇūpamaṃ kāyamimaṃ viditvā, marīcidhammaṃ abhisambudhāno.
chetvāna mārassa papupphakāni, adassanaṃ maccurājassa gacche.

etesaṃ gandhajātānaṃ, sīlagandho anuttaro.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 73 & 74: Ambition and Conceit
snippet.description:

iti bālassa saṅkappo, icchā māno ca vaḍḍhati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 85 and 86: Crossing Over
snippet.description:

athāyaṃ itarā pajā, tīramevānudhāvati.

86. ye ca kho sammadakkhāte, dhamme dhammānuvattino.
te janā pāramessanti, maccudheyyaṃ suduttaraṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 87-89: Brilliant
snippet.description:
87. “kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ vippahāya, sukkaṃ bhāvetha paṇḍito.
okā anokamāgamma, viveke yattha dūramaṃ.

88. “tatrābhiratimiccheyya, hitvā kāme akiñcano.
pariyodapeyya attānaṃ, cittaklesehi paṇḍito.

89. “yesaṃ sambodhiyaṅgesu, sammā cittaṃ subhāvitaṃ.
ādānapaṭinissagge, anupādāya ye ratā.
khīṇāsavā jutimanto, te loke parinibbutā”ti.

Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.description:

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Dhammapada vv. 119 and 120: Ripening
snippet.description:
119. pāpopi passati bhadraṃ, yāva pāpaṃ na paccati.
yadā ca paccati pāpaṃ, atha pāpo pāpāni passati.

120. bhadropi passati pāpaṃ, yāva bhadraṃ na paccati.
yadā ca paccati bhadraṃ, atha bhadro bhadrāni passati.

Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.description:

snippet.description:

attānaṃ upamaṃ katvā, na haneyya na ghātaye.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 131 & 132: Seeking Happiness
snippet.description:
131. sukhakāmāni bhūtāni, yo daṇḍena vihiṃsati.
attano sukhamesāno, pecca so na labhate sukhaṃ.

132. sukhakāmāni bhūtāni, yo daṇḍena na hiṃsati.
attano sukhamesāno, pecca so labhate sukhaṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 133 & 134: A Broken Gong
snippet.description:
133. māvoca pharusaṃ kañci, vuttā paṭivadeyyu taṃ .
dukkhā hi sārambhakathā, paṭidaṇḍā phuseyyu taṃ .

134. sace neresi attānaṃ, kaṃso upahato yathā.
esa pattosi nibbānaṃ, sārambho te na vijjati.


Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 137-140: Harming the Harmless
snippet.description:
137. yo daṇḍena adaṇḍesu, appaduṭṭhesu dussati.
dasannamaññataraṃ ṭhānaṃ, khippameva nigacchati.

138. vedanaṃ pharusaṃ jāniṃ, sarīrassa ca bhedanaṃ .
garukaṃ vāpi ābādhaṃ, cittakkhepañca pāpuṇe.

139. rājato vā upasaggaṃ, abbhakkhānañca dāruṇaṃ.
parikkhayañca ñātīnaṃ, bhogānañca pabhaṅguraṃ .

140. atha vāssa agārāni, aggi ḍahati pāvako.
kāyassa bhedā duppañño, nirayaṃ sopapajjati .

Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Second Life: Ask A Monk
snippet.description:
A morning session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) answering questions for Ask A Monk

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Dependent Origination
snippet.description:
A talk on Dependent Origination as a practical teaching of the Buddha, given in the Deer Park ( http://world.secondlife.com/place/4fb5de1f-7ee5-6408-b078-6a4b90728ae9 ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org/ ) in Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com/ ).

My teaching schedule in SL is currently Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesday at 9 PM (SLT = Pacific Time)

snippet.title: Second Life: Sectarian Buddhism & Elephant Parts
snippet.description:
A morning session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about the problems that come from creating divisions and labels of various Buddhist schools.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Contentment
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about contentment in the Buddha's teaching.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Becoming Buddhist
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about becoming Buddhist

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: The Path to Nibbana (Nirvana)
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about Nibbana and leading guided meditation.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: What is the Buddha's Teaching?
snippet.description:
A morning session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about ways of discerning what is and what is not the Buddha's teaching.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: White Supremacy
snippet.description: An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about white and black in Buddhism and overcoming good and evil.

snippet.title: Second Life: Reacting vs. Experiencing
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about how we react rather than experience, due to the four kinds of partiality.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: How To Succeed in Meditation
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about how to successfully incorporate meditation into one's life for the long term.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Path of Purification
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about the seven parts to the path of purification.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Buddhist Problem Solving
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about the importance of understanding Buddhism as a means of solving the problem in life.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: An Understanding of Mindfulness
snippet.description:
A morning session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) explaining mindfulness and the basis of Buddhist meditation practice.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Making A Change
snippet.description:
An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about using Buddhist meditation teachings to effect a real change in one's life.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Second Life: Perception vs. Reality
snippet.description:
Second Life: Contentment

An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) on the sometimes radical difference between our perceptions and the truth of reality.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Twas the Night Before Kathina
snippet.description: Tomorrow is Kathina at our monastery, I think... I don't know, because no one has told me yet... I think it's supposed to be a surprise.  I do know that 20 monks are coming for breakfast.  I'll be going on alms though, not sure how that fits in with their plans :)

snippet.title: The Nature of Reality (Death, Rebirth and Reincarnation)
snippet.description: An explanation of why it is reasonable to discard a belief in death in favor of an understanding of the constant flow of mind and body phenomena that constitutes reality.

snippet.title: Explaining the Existence of the Mind
snippet.description: This is a video trying to explain to Westerners why it is easier to believe in the existence of the mind as a separate entity from the body than to believe it simply a product of the brain.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind Revisited
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: Absolute Ethics
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the possibility from a scientific point of view of ultimate moral law.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: God and Self
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the incompatibility between the existence of a nature-governed mind and the existence of a self or god.

snippet.title: Ask A Monk: Buddhist Funerals and Relating Conversion

"I come from a very Irish Catholic family but i consider myself to be a Buddhist and have for the past few years. I feel i need to let my friends and family know for the fact that if i was to suddenly die i would have a Catholic funeral instead of a Buddhist funeral and this bothers me. How can i make this announcement easy on them without sounding like a rebel or a show off?"

snippet.title: Punks & Monks - Thai
snippet.description: A Trailer for a potential documentary on people who leave society to find another way to live.  For more info, contact www.livingfilms.com

snippet.title: The Alms Round and Monk's Life
snippet.description: Some random thoughts on the alms round and what it means to be a monk.  This was created in conjunction with our How To Meditate DVD that is available for free at http://www.sirimangalo.org/videos

snippet.title: Private video
snippet.description: This video is private.

snippet.title: Chanting at Wat Thai Minnesota
snippet.description: The introductory chanting in the living room of the house converted into the Thai monastery in Elk River, Minnesota

snippet.title: Alms Round in North Hollywood
snippet.description: A simple video of my alms round in North Hollywood.  Note that no begging is involved, the people give because they feel that giving is good, and because of the teaching that they receive from the monks in return.

snippet.title: How To Meditate DVD Menu
snippet.description:
A preview of the menu on the How To Meditate DVD.  For more information on getting a free copy of this DVD, visit here:

http://www.sirimangalo.org/videos

or watch this video:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=myd6nqYvSkc

snippet.title: Vigilance
snippet.description: 32x sunset video taken in the Mohave Desert, accompanied by my teacher's words on vigilance.

snippet.title: Buddhist Concept of Suffering (Mohave Desert Clips)
snippet.description: Part of a talk on the four noble truths given in North Hollywood.  The video is from our ten-day meditation course in the Mohave Desert, Jan 2010.

snippet.title: Guide to Taking Five Precepts and Three Refuges
snippet.description:
For people wishing to take the five Buddhist precepts (not to kill, steal, cheat, lie, or take intoxicants) and the three refuges (the Buddha, his teachings, and his enlightened followers).  Use this guide at home to take the precepts and refuges by yourself.

Note: for Pali transcript and English translation, turrn on subtitles by pressing "CC"  You can also download the subtitle file here:

http://www.sirimangalo.org/files/subtitles/fiveprecepts.srt

snippet.title: Questions on Meditation: What Should We See?
snippet.description: An answer to the question of what we should realize from the practice of meditation.

snippet.title: What Meditation Is Not
snippet.description: A short cautionary note on dealing with "special" states encountered in meditation.  The answer is to understand that there is no state that should be judged as more special than another, but simply to see and acknowledge everything as it is, for what it is.

snippet.title: Enlightenment
snippet.description: Two different takes on the word "Enlightenment" as it relates to meditation practice.

snippet.title: ประวัติ  พระธรรมมังคลาจารย์
snippet.description:
พระอุปัชฌาย์ของผม (a biography of my preceptor)

พระธรรมมังคลาจารย์ (หลวงพ่อทอง สิริมงฺคโล)
Phra Dhammamangalajaan (Luang Bpu Tong Sirimangalo)
วัดพระธาตุศรีจอมทองวรวิหาร
Wat Phradhatu Sri Chom Tong Voravihara
ต.บ้านหลวง อ.จอมทอง จ.เชียงใหม่
T. Baan Luang A. Chom Tong J. Chiang Mai

snippet.title: How To Meditate I - What is Meditation
snippet.description: First (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses both the meaning of meditation and the foundations of meditation practice.

snippet.title: How To Meditate II - Sitting Meditation
snippet.description: Second (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses a simple technique of sitting meditation.

snippet.title: How To Meditate III - Walking Meditation
snippet.description: Third (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video demonstrates a simple technique of walking meditation.

snippet.title: How To Meditate IV - Fundamentals of Meditation Practice
snippet.description: Fourth (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses some fundamental qualities that are essential to the meditation practice.

snippet.title: How To Meditate V - Mindful Prostration
snippet.description: how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video demonstrates the technique of mindful prostration, a sort of warm-up exercise before the walking and sitting, with the added benefit of creating humility and respect towards the meditation practice.

snippet.title: How To Meditate VI - Meditation Practice and Daily Life
snippet.description: Sixth (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses some of the ways to incorporate meditation practice into one's daily life, as well as some of the things that must be moderated or done away with if one expects the meditation to have a real effect on one's daily life.

snippet.title: The Object of Meditation
snippet.description: My first vblog entry, talking briefly about the point of meditation and mindfulness.

snippet.title: Changing the World Inside
snippet.description: Just some musings about where one can expect to effect real change in this world.

snippet.title: A Spiritual Tourist
snippet.description: Sort of a vacation-feel to this clip.  Just thought I'd say hello, and give some thoughts on the viability of living as a meditator in and amongst the very things we have taken out of our own lives.

snippet.title: Thailand: Above the World
snippet.description:
Things have changed a lot at Chom Tong since I first visited here 11 years ago.  Some things haven't changed, and one is the difficulty such a place presents, both externally and internally.  The only solution here and everywhere else is to rise above the external difficulties by overcoming the internal ones.

snippet.title: Buddhist Meditation Masters Clip
snippet.description:
An American went to India around 1969 with an 8mm camera and visited Munindra on retreat with his students, Dipa Ma in Calcutta, and Mahasi Sayadaw in Burma at the Sasana Yietkha.  This rare footage of long since deceased masters of meditation. For more information and info on how to get the whole film shipped anywhere in the world on DVD you can visit my site www.begintosee.com The full length version of this video is now available to watch on Google Video.

Buy Mirka Knaster's new book about the life of Munindra, "Living the Life Fully" at amazon.com: 

http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=living+the+life+fully+munindra&x=0&y=0

snippet.title: Giant Buddha Statue Nears Completion in India
snippet.description:
CHAN: A huge Buddha statue is being built in India's Northern Sarnath province. The statue is one of the tallest in the world and stands where Lord Buddha delivered his first sermon.

STORY: Indian sculptors are chiseling an eighty feet tall statue. Only the Bamiyan valley statues in Afghanistan are taller.

The project started ten years ago, but stopped because of lack of money. Now with the help of the Thailand Government the sculptors are nearly finished.

[Jyoti Singh Khushwaha, Contractor]: "Twenty to twenty five artisans are working on this since 3-4 years...its going to take three more years to complete."

Workers say the statue will use over 635 blocks of sandstone. The Gandharva style of art puts great emphasis on detail.

[Mohan Lal, Statue Designer]: "It will be the tallest statue of Buddha in a standing position and it comes second in height only to the Bamiyan Buddha (statues). It has been more than 10 years since we began work."

Sarnath is located ten kilometers from India's northern pilgrim town of Varanasi. It is the place where Buddha is believed to have given his first sermon in 500 B.C.

Buddha was born a prince at Lumbini in Nepal over 2,600 years ago. He attained enlightenment at the age of 35 in Bodh Gaya in India's eastern Bihar.

The Buddha left the world at the age of 80 in Kushinagar.

snippet.title: World's Tallest Statue (BBC)
snippet.description: Maitreya Project's 500ft / 152m bronze statue will be built at Kushinagar, Uttar Pradesh in northern India. The Maitreya Buddha statue and its throne-building will provide the public with temples, exhibition halls, a museum, library, audio-visual theatre and hospitality services. All will be set in beautifully landscaped parks with meditation pavilions, beautiful water fountains and tranquil pools. The buildings and grounds of the Project will contain a remarkable and inspiring collection of sacred art.

snippet.title: With a View to Nibbana (Part 1)
snippet.description:
University of Toronto, July 12, 2009 
Presented at Hart House
by Sean M. Smith


Abstract:

This talk will present an argument about the idiosyncratic nature of the Buddhas teaching. It will attempt to establish the uniqueness of the Buddhas path and to distinguish it from various models of Western thought. The main concept in Buddhism that I will utilize to make this contrast effective is Nibbana; the final Goal of the Buddhas path of practice. By establishing the uniqueness of Nibbana I hope to demonstrate that the recent trend of borrowing piecemeal from the Buddhas teaching carries with it the risk of distorting the message of Dhamma. The Western models I will use to help in this exploration are psychotherapy, neuroscience and philosophy of mind. I also wish to discuss in some detail other important elements of the Buddhas teaching. be free from physical suffering

in this dwelling
in this compound

be free from physical suffering

All beings are owners of their own Kamma

to as far down as the lowest plane

snippet.title: Morality & Wisdom are Supreme in the World
snippet.description:
From the historic printing in 1893 to the first digital edition in 2010

This brief video shows the 39-volume Chulachomklao of Siam Pāḷi Tipiṭaka being preserved at the International Tipiṭaka Hall, Chulalongkorn University. 

This historic edition is the world's first printed set of the Tipiṭaka in book-form. As a royal gift of Dhamma, the King presented these sets to over the kingdom of Siam in 1893 and two years later, upon a request, also present them to over 260 institutes in 30 countries worldwide. 

The Tipiṭaka in Siam script provided indispensable phonetic information for the standard transliteration for Pāḷi pronunciation for the World Tipiṭaka Project in Roman Script.      

In commemoration of the King's vision, a digital project was launched in 2000 to digitalise the complete set of the Sia-script edition. The project was completed in 2009, and the 2010 edition (40 volumes, including Vol.40, Anthology Volume) is presented in this video with Tipiṭaka patrons, who are respectfully photographed with the portrait of King Chulalongkorn Chulachomklao, the Great Dhamma & Tipiṭaka Protector.  

World Tipiṭaka Recitation : Sīlapaññā with EngFrom the historic printing in 1893 to the first digital edition in 2010

snippet.title: The Killing Fields
snippet.description:
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambodia_under_Pol_Pot_(1975-1979)
The worst humanity can muster, a sad epic in the history of man, and not well known in the rest of the world. Pol Pot, leader of the Khmer Rouge from 1975 to 1979, claimed to have eliminated 800,000 people, while estimates run as high as 3 million killed not only by death camps and squads, but by the following chaos and starvation. 25 to 30% of the entire country's population at the time.
This video features snapshots from Tuol Sleng S-21 prison/extermination camp, where 20000 people went through and there are 7 known survivors. There are paintings done by one of the survivors that show the atrocities committed by the Khmer Rouge. Photos at the Killing Fields were taken in heavy rain, which washed away the dirt and exposed more bones that were strewn everywhere, even along the PATH we were WALKING ON.
I witnessed areas of Cambodia where an entire generation is simply missing. Children are working because there are simply not enough adults to run businesses and do labor.
It is a heartbreaking story that must be remembered in order to prevent it from happening again.
Put an end to genocide~

snippet.title: With a View to Nibbana (Part 1)
snippet.description:
University of Toronto, July 12, 2009 
Presented at Hart House
by Sean M. Smith


Abstract:

This talk will present an argument about the idiosyncratic nature of the Buddhas teaching. It will attempt to establish the uniqueness of the Buddhas path and to distinguish it from various models of Western thought. The main concept in Buddhism that I will utilize to make this contrast effective is Nibbana; the final Goal of the Buddhas path of practice. By establishing the uniqueness of Nibbana I hope to demonstrate that the recent trend of borrowing piecemeal from the Buddhas teaching carries with it the risk of distorting the message of Dhamma. The Western models I will use to help in this exploration are psychotherapy, neuroscience and philosophy of mind. I also wish to discuss in some detail other important elements of the Buddhas teaching. In addition to Nibbana, some examples are the Four Noble Truths, The Eightfold Noble Path, The Three marks of existence, The Seven Factors of Enlightenment and The Ten Virtues. By explaining these ideas (and others) properly and on their own terms and contrasting them with various western ideas, I hope to make the lines of commitment clear on both sides so that the project of mutual influence can continue in a respectful and wise manner. In this way the talk will also serve as an introduction to the main tenants of the Buddhas teaching.

snippet.title: A New Perspective On Bipolar Disorder, Depression, Mania, Hallucinations, and Delusion
snippet.description:
http://www.bipolaradvantage.com What is unfortunate today is that far too many people continue to cling to the old belief that it is impossible to live a full life with a mental condition. On the other hand, a growing group of people are beginning to consider a life that is not restricted to a narrow range of experience. I look forward to the day when we all rise above the ignorance that keeps us in fear and denial of a better life.

Bipolar In Order is based on a very simple premise: we can learn and grow to the point that we see our condition as an advantage in our lives. Because this concept is often difficult for many people to accept on blind faith alone, I encourage everyone to simply begin by accepting that this new perspective is possible. To make this perspective a reality requires persistence, determination, and commitment. If you will give this perspective a chance, you will prove it in your own life.

There are so many examples of bipolar "disorder" that it is easy to understand why so many people try to avoid it instead of facing it and getting it under control. We can choose to view depression, mania, hallucination, and delusion from at least two different perspectives--either as "disorder" or as "in order." Knowing that we have a choice of perspectives leads us to the understanding that we do not have to accept a diminished life. We begin to see what bipolar can be if we get it "in order" instead of trying to make it go away.

For me, Bipolar In Order is the greatest state there is. Once you begin to see the new perspective, everything changes. You see why the current approach of avoidance is all wrong. You cannot get to Bipolar In Order by figuring out how to avoid the symptoms. Avoidance is accepting a diminished life tragically below that which is possible. This book is about what bipolar looks like from the perspective of "in order" and how you can achieve it in your own life.

snippet.title: Alva Noë | Talks at Google
snippet.description:
Alva Noë visits Google's San Francisco, CA office to discuss his book "Out of Our Heads: Why You Are Not Your Brain, and Other Lessons from the Biology of Consciousness." This event took place on April 16, 2009, as part of the Authors@Google series.

The notion that consciousness is confined to the brain, like software in a computer, has dominated science and philosophy for close to two centuries. Yet, according to this incisive review of contemporary neuroscience from Berkeley philosopher Noë, the analogy is deeply flawed. In eight illuminating, mercifully jargon-free chapters, he defines what scientists really know about consciousness and makes a strong case that mind and awareness are processes that arise during a dynamic dance with the observers surroundings. Noë begins with a sharp critique of scientists, such as DNA co-discoverer Francis Crick, who insist that nothing but neurons determines our daily perceptions and sense of self. He then examines studies of human and animal behavior that demonstrate an inextricable link between identity and environment. Noë regrettably limits his treatise by ignoring considerable research from transpersonal psychology suggesting that consciousness transcends physicality altogether. Still, the resulting book is an invaluable contribution to cognitive science and the branch of self-reflective philosophy extending back to Descartes famous maxim, I think, therefore I am.

snippet.title: Christopher Hitchens: Pascal's wager = religious hucksterism
snippet.description:
Christopher Hitchens discusses Pascal's wager.

This is during the LBJ Future Forum on May 14, 2007, at the LBJ Library and Museum in Austin, Texas.

http://lbjfutureforum.org/events/events_details.cfm?ID=110

After a debate with Marvin Olasky, Christopher Hitchens responds to a question from audience member Craig Estes.

Hitchens sums up Blaise Pascal's wager with this memorable imagery:
"Religious hucksterism of the cheapest, vulgarest, nastiest kind it's possible to imagine. He says, 'What have you got to lose? I've got a good offer for you. Come into my used car lot. Come on baby, just lie a little, and you never know!' No, don't talk to me like that, and don't call it piety when you do, or be prepared to have piety despised."

snippet.title: My stroke of insight | Jill Bolte Taylor
snippet.description: http://www.ted.com  Neuroanatomist Jill Bolte Taylor had an opportunity few brain scientists would wish for: One morning, she realized she was having a massive stroke. As it happened -- as she felt her brain functions slip away one by one, speech, movement, understanding -- she studied and remembered every moment. This is a powerful story about how our brains define us and connect us to the world and to one another.

snippet.title: Monk Life ชีวิตสมณะ (English)
snippet.description:
http://www.dmc.tv/en/
---Monk Life--- 
Like a bird that flies from its nest. As it soars it feel no regrets Seek a life that has more worth, Search the path till they reach ... all » Nirvana. 

Garments they have merely three. Day and night feeling joy sharing peace, With only essential need of life, Nourished by food from those who believe. 

They practice and train through Meditation, With Kantha, Vipassana; at all times. Dhamma principles worth more than their own life. Hope to stop rebirth, defeat... Mara. 

Chorus * 

They will journey to benefit the world. Overcome all the suffering; end sorrow, Like sun that brightens up the darkest universe. The world will be, filled with joy through Dhammakaya. 

And thus, is the life of a Monk Who devotes their life to the truth This they vow till death, To the Lord Buddha. Till the end they'll fight for peace, to defeat. . . Mara.

snippet.title: World's Tallest Statue (BBC)
snippet.description: Maitreya Project's 500ft / 152m bronze statue will be built at Kushinagar, Uttar Pradesh in northern India. The Maitreya Buddha statue and its throne-building will provide the public with temples, exhibition halls, a museum, library, audio-visual theatre and hospitality services. All will be set in beautifully landscaped parks with meditation pavilions, beautiful water fountains and tranquil pools. The buildings and grounds of the Project will contain a remarkable and inspiring collection of sacred art.

snippet.title: Giant Buddha Statue Nears Completion in India
snippet.description:
CHAN: A huge Buddha statue is being built in India's Northern Sarnath province. The statue is one of the tallest in the world and stands where Lord Buddha delivered his first sermon.

STORY: Indian sculptors are chiseling an eighty feet tall statue. Only the Bamiyan valley statues in Afghanistan are taller.

The project started ten years ago, but stopped because of lack of money. Now with the help of the Thailand Government the sculptors are nearly finished.

[Jyoti Singh Khushwaha, Contractor]: "Twenty to twenty five artisans are working on this since 3-4 years...its going to take three more years to complete."

Workers say the statue will use over 635 blocks of sandstone. The Gandharva style of art puts great emphasis on detail.

[Mohan Lal, Statue Designer]: "It will be the tallest statue of Buddha in a standing position and it comes second in height only to the Bamiyan Buddha (statues). It has been more than 10 years since we began work."

Sarnath is located ten kilometers from India's northern pilgrim town of Varanasi. It is the place where Buddha is believed to have given his first sermon in 500 B.C.

Buddha was born a prince at Lumbini in Nepal over 2,600 years ago. He attained enlightenment at the age of 35 in Bodh Gaya in India's eastern Bihar.

The Buddha left the world at the age of 80 in Kushinagar.

snippet.title: Doi Suthep Temple Thailand พระธาตุดอยสุเทพ จังหวัด เชียงใหม่
snippet.description:
It is the holy place of Buddhist and Lanna history. It located on Doi Suthep, Muang District, Chiang Mai Province, Thailand.  The monument was established on B.E.1927 (1384), there is 306 steps spread to the upper building. The building is Peguan style chedi, which contained remains of Lord Buddha.
Visit at www.doisuthep.com/english.html

snippet.title: Buddhist Meditation Masters Clip
snippet.description:
An American went to India around 1969 with an 8mm camera and visited Munindra on retreat with his students, Dipa Ma in Calcutta, and Mahasi Sayadaw in Burma at the Sasana Yietkha.  This rare footage of long since deceased masters of meditation. For more information and info on how to get the whole film shipped anywhere in the world on DVD you can visit my site www.begintosee.com The full length version of this video is now available to watch on Google Video.

Buy Mirka Knaster's new book about the life of Munindra, "Living the Life Fully" at amazon.com: 

http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=living+the+life+fully+munindra&x=0&y=0
